choices.text: E. Coli colonisation of the colon

questions.text: Which of the following is a plasmid borne virulence factor?
questions.solution:
Surface antigens responsible for colonisation of the intestinal wall by E. coli is an example of plasmid mediated virulence.

Diphtheria toxin production is a classical example of phage directed virulence. In the diphtheria bacilli, the gene for toxin production is present in beta or other tox+ corynephages.

Adhesins in E. coli. are surface antigens.

Exotoxin production is responsible for virulence by Vibrio cholera.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, pg. 76.

questions.text: One of the pioneers in reducing surgical sepsis using methods of disinfection and sterilisation was?
questions.solution:
The introduction of antiseptic techniques in surgery by Joseph Lister (1867), effected a pronounced drop in mortality and morbidity due to surgical sepsis. Lister's antiseptic surgery involving the use of carbolic acid was a milestone in the evolution of surgical practice, from the era of 'laudable pus' to modern aseptic techniques.

Reference - The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, pg.4

questions.text: Which of the following is used to cultivate fastidious organisms?
questions.solution:
Brain heart infusion broth-

  • Most suited to grow fastidious organisms.
  • It is an enriched medium.
  • It is highly nutritious, buffered fluid culture medium prepared by non-enzymatic infusion from calf brain and cow heart, often with peptone and dextrose

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, pg. 40.

choices.text: Mutation which involves vital functions making such mutants non-viable.
Reversal of a mutant phenotype by another mutation at a position on the DNA distinct from that of the original mutation.
Mutation where the triplet code is altered so as to specify an amino acid different from that normally located at a particular position in the protein.
Deletion of a nucleotide within a gene may cause premature polypeptide chain termination.

questions.text: Missense mutation in bacteria can be described as:
questions.solution:
Types of mutations in bacteria -

  • Missense mutation - Mutation where the triplet code is altered so as to specify an amino acid different from that normally located at a articular position in the protein.
  • Nonsense mutation - Deletion of a nucleotide within a gene may cause premature polypeptide chain termination by generating a nonsense codon.
  • Suppressor mutation - Reversal of a mutant phenotype by another mutation at a position on the DNA distinct from that of the original mutation.
  • Transversion - Substitution of a purine for a pyramidine and vice versa in base pairing.
  • Lethal mutation - Some mutations involve vital functions, and such mutants are non-viable.
  • Conditional lethal mutant - Ability to live under certain conditions (permissive conditions).

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology. Pg 57.

questions.text: Patient complains of swollen lymph glands, fatigue, visual disturbance, and history of a painless sore on the genitals. Which of the following staining methods can be used to recognise the microorganism causing it?
questions.solution:
The symptoms mentioned indicate the second stage of syphilis, caused by a spirochetes - T. Pallidum .

Very slender bacteria such as spirochetes, are not demonstrable by simple staining methods. They can be viewed by negative staining using Indian ink (i.e. nigrosin).

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, pg. 12.; 372.

choices.text: Low lipid content of the staphylococcus

questions.text: The differential stain of a Staphylococcus shows red color. This phenomenon is due to
questions.solution:
Gram stain is a differential stain which differentiates bacteria in to two broad categories:

  • Gram-positive bacteria are those that resist decolourisation and retain the primary stain appearing violet.
  • Gram-negative bacteria are decolourised by organic solvents and, therefore, take the counterstain, appearing

Staphylococci are gram positive. Gram-positive bacteria become Gram negative when the cell wall is damaged.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, pg. 13

questions.text: Which of the following bacteria will have stable distinctive morphology?
questions.solution:
Sarcina is cluster of 8 cocci bacteria.

Mycoplasma are bacteria that are cell wall deficient and hence do not possess a stable morphology.

When cell wall synthesis becomes defective, as a result of drugs like penicillin or vancomycin (glycopeptide inhibitors), bacteria lose their distinctive shape.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, pg. 14.

choices.text: Gamma hemolysis: Complete clearing of the blood agar medium surrounding the colonies.
Alpha hemolysis: Complete clearing of the blood agar medium surrounding the colonies.
Beta hemolysis: A greenish discolouration of agar around the colonies.
Gamma hemolysis: Results in no change of the blood agar.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly matches the type of result on blood agar?
questions.solution:
Blood agar can indicate the degree of hemolysis caused by hemolysin. Based on this, it is, used to differentiate among Gram-positive cocci.

  • Beta hemolysis refers to complete lysis of the red blood cells and haemoglobin. This results in complete clearing of the blood agar medium surrounding the colonies.

Ex: Group A Streptococci

  • Alpha hemolysis refers to the partial lysis of red blood cells and haemoglobin. This results in a greenish discolouration of the agar around the colonies.

Ex: Viridans Streptococci

  • Gamma hemolysis refers to no hemolysis. Hence there is no change in colour of blood agar.

Ex: Enterococci

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, pg. 40

questions.text: Which Hepatitis virus remains unaffected on heating 60°C for an hour, subjecting to acid at pH 3 and anionic detergents?
questions.solution:
HAV is resistant to inactivation by heat at 60°C for one hour, ether and acid at pH 3, but is inactivated by boiling for one minute, 1:4000 formaldehyde at 37°C for 72 hours, and chlorine 1 ppm for 30 minutes. It is not affected by anionic detergents.

HBV is relatively heat stable but susceptible to chemical agents.

HCV is sensitive to heat.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, pg. 545, 555.

choices.text: It is potentially toxic to human beings, causing mutagenicity and carcinogenicity.
It is suitable for the fumigation of rooms.
It is effective against all types of microorganisms, including viruses and spores.
It reacts with DNA and RNA.

questions.text: Which of the following doesn't hold true about Ethylene oxide as a chemical agent?
questions.solution:
Ethylene oxide is unsuitable for fumigating rooms because of its explosive property. It is also an irritant.

Ethylene oxide -

  • It is potentially toxic to humans and does possess mutagenicity and carcinogenicity.
  • It also reacts with DNA and RNA (rendering them virucidal).
  • It acts by alkylating the amino, carboxyl, hydroxyl and sulphydryl groups in protein molecules within the microbes and spores.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, pg. 34

questions.text: Which of the following kills all microbial pathogens including spores with longer period of contact?
questions.solution:
• High-level disinfectant is a chemical that kills all microbial pathogensexceptlarge numbers ofspores. It may have some activity against a smaller number of spores if the contact time is increased. For example, glutaraldehyde and hydrogen peroxide.
  • Intermediate-level disinfectant is a chemical that kills all microbial pathogens including mycobacteria and non-enveloped viruses except spores. For example, alcohol, phenolic compounds and iodophores.
  • Low-level disinfectant is a chemical that kills only vegetative bacteria, fungi and lipid-enveloped viruses. For example, quaternary ammonium compound.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology,'s Textbook of Microbiology; pg 37

choices.text: Bacteriostatic in low dilution and active against gram positive bacteria
Bacteriostatic in high dilution and more active against gram positive bacteria
Bactericidal in high dilution and active against gram negative bacteria
Bactericidal in low dilution and more active against gram negative bacteria

questions.text: Aniline and acridine are
questions.solution:
Dyes aniline and acridine are used extensively as skin and wound antiseptics. Both are bacteriostaticin high dilution but have low bactericidal activity. They are more active against Gram-positive than Gram-negative bacteria.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology,'s Textbook of Microbiology pg. 34.

questions.text: Which of the following antiseptics will be used for treatment of wounds for which gram status is not known?
questions.solution:
Chlorhexidine (Hibitane) is a relatively non-toxic skin antiseptic and wound dressing. They are active against most Gram-positive organisms and fairly effective against Gram-negative bacteria both.

Lysol and cresol are active against a wide range of organisms. Though they are good general disinfectants, they are toxic to humans.

Chlorophenol is inactivated by organic substances like pus.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology's, Textbook of Microbiology, pg 35.

questions.text: Which of the following is used to clean incubators?
questions.solution:
Methyl alcohol is highly effective against fungal spores. It is used for cleaning cabinets andincubators. Insides of the chambers are wiped with liberal amounts of methanol.

Ethyl alcohol is used mainly as skin antiseptic at a concentration of 60% to 90% in water. They act by denaturing bacterial proteins but have no action on spores.

Iodine in an aqueous and alcoholic solution has been widely used as a skin disinfectant. It is bactericidal, with moderate action against spores.

Chlorine is used as disinfectant which is markedly bactericidal and virucidal. Town water supplies, swimming pools, food and dairy industries use chlorine for disinfection. The organic chloramines are used as antiseptics for dressing wounds.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 33.

questions.text: Surface active agents are used as all except:
questions.solution:
Surface-active agents are substances that alter the energy relationship at interfaces, producing a reduction in surface tension. They are widely used as wetting agents, detergents and emulsifiers.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 35.

questions.text: Sterilisation method of heat sensitive articles such as arthroscopes and urethroscopes utilises which of the following compounds?
questions.solution:
Plasma sterilisation is a new method of sterilisation of heat sensitive articles like arthroscopes, urethroscopes.

  • Plasma is known as the fourth state of matter and consists of ions, electrons or neutral particles.
  • A radio frequency energy is applied to create an electromagnetic field.
  • Into this, hydrogen peroxide vapours are introduced which generates a state of plasma containing free radicals of hydrogen and oxygen.
  • This state renders the articles sterile by denaturing all microorganisms.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, pg 37.

choices.text: Soft, Brown to black: Madurella mycetomatis
Hard, Brown to black: Madurella grisea

questions.text: A farmer in Tamil Nadu complains of painless subcutaneous swelling in the foot following a minor trauma. The fluid from sinuses shows granules. Which of the following are most likely features of the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The disease describes mycetoma. It is commonly known as Maduramycosis or Madura foot.

The entirely correct description of characters is hard, brown to black: Madurella grisea which is a eumycetoma.

Reference -

From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, table 63.4, pg 605

choices.text: White bodies without septae known as sclerotic bodies.
Dark brown bodies without septae known as chromotic bodies.
White bodies without septae known as sclerotic bodies.
Dark brown bodies with septae known as sclerotic bodies.

questions.text: The most common form of chromomycosis is identified by :
questions.solution:
Chromoblastomycosis (verrucous dermatitis) is the most common form of chromomycosis.

  • The lesions show fungus as round or irregular, dark brown, yeast-like bodies with septae, called sclerotic bodies.
  • Diagnosis can be established by demonstration of these sclerotic bodies in KOH mounts or in tissue sections, and by culture on Sabouraud agar.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 605.

questions.text:
Which of the colonies of dermatophytes are correctly described below?
i Trichophyton: Colonies may be powdery, velvety or waxy, with pigmentation characteristic of different species. Infects the hair and nails but not the skin.
ii Microsporum: Colonies are cotton-like, velvety or powdery, with white to brown pigmentation. Infects skin and nails but not hair.
iii Epidermophyton: Colonies are powdery and greenish yellow. Infects hair and skin but usually not nails.
questions.solution: Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, pg 602

questions.text: Patient complains of polyps in the nose and mouth, which bleed on touch after working in water for some time. Histology shows: spherules embedded in stroma with thousands of endospores. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
• Rhinosporidium seeberi is a fungus which causes Rhinosporidiosis.
  • This is a chronic granulomatous disease characterised by the development of friable polyps, usually confined to the nose, mouth or eye but rarely seen on the genitalia or other mucous membranes.
  • Histologically, the lesion is composed of large number of fungal spherules embedded in stroma of connective tissue and capillaries.
  • The spherules are 10-200 μm in diameter and contain thousands endospores.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, pg 606 and 607.

choices.text: Short broad fragmented hyphae with beak-like projections.

questions.text: History of patient gives an insect bite, followed by development of painless subcutaneous nodule which enlarged to involve the whole limb. The histologic examination will show
questions.solution:
The history describes subcutaneous zygomycosis or entomophthoromycoses.

  • The causative organism is Conidiobolus coronatus and Basidiobolus ranarum (saprophytic zygomycetes found in decaying vegetation).
  • A painless subcutaneous nodule develops which enlarges to involve a whole limb or large areas of the body.
  • The lesions are now known to be acquired by insect bites.
  • The causative fungi can be isolated by culture.
  • Histopathological examination shows the presence of short, broad fragmented hyphae with beak-like projections.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, pg 607.

questions.text: Culture of a lesion, developed after a horn prick, shows a dimorphic fungus at 37°C. It's septate hyphae are 1-2 μm in diameter and carry flower like clusters of small conidia borne on delicate sterigmata. It's serology will be done through:
questions.solution:
History indicates sporotrichosis. The dimorphic fungus is Sporothrix schenckii.

A slide latex agglutination test, using peptido- L-rhamno-D-mannan (outer layer of the fungal cell wall) as antigen, is a reliable, sensitive and specific test. Results are obtained in minutes.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, Pg. 606

choices.text: Forms chlamydospores on corn meal agar.
Smooth colonies on corn meal agar

questions.text: An organism shows germ tube formation at 37° when incubated in human serum. Which of the following is also true for the same organism?
questions.solution:
The history indicates Candida albicans.

A rapid method of identifying C.albicans is based on its ability to form germ tubes within two hours when incubated in human serum at 37°C (Reynolds-Braude phenomenon).

C. albicans alone forms chlamydospores on corn meal agar cultures at 20°C.

Option a - Wet films or Gram-stained smears of C. albicans show budding Gram-positive cells.

Option b - Colonies of C albicans on Sabouraud agar are creamy white, smooth and with a yeasty odour.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology Pg. 616.

choices.text: Double shelled and rough surface in larger form
Single shelled and smooth surface in larger form
Double shelled and smooth surface in larger form
Single shelled and smooth surface in larger form

questions.text: The causative agent of the most common cause of diarrheal disease in infants and children possess
questions.solution:
Rotavirus is the most common cause of diarrheal disease in infants and children.

  • The complete or 'double-shelled' virus measures about 70 nm in diameter and has a smooth surface.
  • The incomplete or 'single-shelled' virus is smaller, about 60 nm, with a rough surface that has lost the outer shell.
  • 'Empty' particles without the RNA core are also seen.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology. Pg. 564.

questions.text:
A group of spherical or pleomorphic enveloped RNA viruses carries peplomers and responsible for a highly transmittable infection beginning with fever, cough and presenting at times with diarrhoea. Which of following is the incorrect correspondence of its two group?
I. Acid-labile viruses : associated with common cold-like illnesses.
II. Acid- stable viruses : associated with human and animal gastroenteritis.
III. Acid- labile viruses : associated with human and animal gastroenteritis
IV. Acid- stable viruses: associated with common cold-like illnesses.
questions.solution:
• Corona viruses are a group of spherical or pleomorphic enveloped RNA viruses, carrying petal- or club-shaped peplomers on their surface.
  • The name refers to the fringe of surface projections surrounding the virus, resembling the solar corona.
  • There are two groups: acid-labile viruses (associated with common cold-like illnesses) and acid- stable viruses (associated with human and animal gastroenteritis).

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology. Pg. 446.

questions.text: A 7 year old complains of a generalised rash that developed on the face, spreading to the neck, trunk and extremities except the palms and soles. There is non-tender swelling over the posterior cervical nodes. Diagnostic measure employed as mainstay is:
questions.solution:
The infection described is classical rubella and the mainstay of diagnosis is serological antibody demonstration by ELISA.

Rubella shows a generalised rash that developed on the face, spreading to the neck, trunk and extremities except the palms and soles. There is non-tender enlargement of the posterior cervical lymph nodes.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology. Pg 559.

choices.text: Preferred culture is done through monkey kidney cell
Antigenically stable and multiple serotypes exist
The virus may be isolated from saliva within 4-5 days and in urine up to two weeks
Virus growth can be identified by hemadsorption

questions.text: For the virus given in the diagram, which is not true?
questions.solution:
• Mumps virus given in the diagram is antigenically stable and only one serotype
  • Cell cultures are better suited for isolation -primary monkey kidney being the preferred cell.
  • The cytopathic effect is slow and consists of syncytium formation and the presence of acidophilic cytoplasmic inclusions.
  • Growth is best identified by hemadsorption.
  • The mumps virus is labile, being rapidly inactivated at room temperature or by exposure to formaldehyde, ether or ultraviolet light.
  • The virus may be isolated from saliva (within 4-5 days), urine (up to two weeks) or CSF (8-9 days after onset of illness).

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology. Pg 513.

choices.text: IgM anti Hbs and Anti Hbc

questions.text: A truck driver complains of fatigue, loss of appetite, nausea since a few weeks with recent onset of vomiting. Lab results show elevated serum bilirubin and and liver enzymes with high HbsAg. Serology will show peaks of?
questions.solution:
The above disease describes hepatitis B in its prodrome, concluded from onset of symptoms as well as high HbsAg.

For hepatitis, prodrome and acute infection set in from 2.5 to 4 months where high titres of both IgM anti Hbs and Anti Hbc are found.

Anti Hbe peak indicates early convalescence while HbcAg is not demonstrable in circulation because it is enclosed within the HBsAg coat.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology. Pg 550, 551. Fig. 58.6.

choices.text: It is resistant to ether, chloroform, bile, proteolytic enzymes of the intestinal contents and detergents
Diagnosis done by complement fixation method
Poliovirus survive lyophilisation very well but not in milk or ice cream

questions.text: Which of the following is not true for the pathogen immunised by Salk and Sabin vaccines?
questions.solution:
The salk and sabin vaccines are employed for Poliomyelitis.

Poliovirus does not survive lyophilisation.

It is readily inactivated by heat (55°C for 30 minutes). Molar MgCl2 protects the virus against heat inactivation. Milk or ice cream also provides such protection.

Immunity in poliomyelitis is type-specific and permanent.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, pg 491.

questions.text: For the given diagram, the technique utilised is?
questions.solution:
The given diagram shows intracytoplasmic 'Negri bodies' which are the inclusion bodies.

Diagnosis of Rabies in animals like dogs may be made postmortem by demonstration of Negri bodies in the brain. Negri bodies are seen as intracytoplasmic, round or oval, purplish pink structures with characteristic basophilic inner granules.

Seller's stain utilising basic fuchsin and methylene blue in methanol, is classically utilised.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, pg 538.

choices.text: Virus which is largest type of herpes viruse

questions.text: Owl's eye deposits are seen in which of the following infections?
questions.solution:
Owl's eye deposits describe inclusion bodies of CMV virus which is the largest of the herpes viruses being 150 to 200 nm in size.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, pg 479, 480.

questions.text: Which of the following induces hemorrhagic necrosis in certain tumours and causes cachexia in chronic infections?
questions.solution:
TNF alpha induces hemorrhagic necrosis and results in cachexia in long term infections.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, pg. 157

questions.text: Which of the following is not a property of cytokine?
questions.solution:
• Cytokines are peptide mediators or intercellular messengers that regulate immunological, inflammatory and reparative host response.
  • They are highly potent hormone-like substances, active even at femtomolar (10- 15M) concentrations.
  • They are produced by widely distributed cells (such as lymphocytes, macrophages, platelets and fibroblasts).
  • They act locally near the producing cells (paracrine effect) or directly on the producing cells themselves (autocrine effect).
  • They are pleiotropic.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, pg. 155.

choices.text: Susan Black B stain - Protein globules can be made out
Agar plates with inverted fir tree appearance
Amorphous purplish capsule on test with polychrome methylene blue.

questions.text: Which holds true for the pathogen causing satellite lesions covered with eschars?
questions.solution:
The satellite lesions covered with eschar are characteristic of cutaneous anthrax.

Amorphous purplish capsule on testing with polychrome methylene blue is the M'Fadyean's reaction. This is characteristic of anthrax bacilli.

Option a - Susan Black B stain - Fat globules can be made out.

Option b - It is a facultative anaerobe.

Option c - On gelatin stab culture, inverted fir tree appearance is seen.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 251.

questions.text: The action of lysozyme results in
questions.solution:
Spheroplast: When lysozyme acts on Gram-negative bacteria, the result is a spheroplast which differs from the the protoplast in that some cell wall material is retained.

Protoplast: When lysozyme acts on a Gram-positive bacterium in a hypertonic solution, a protoplast is formed, consisting of the cytoplasmic membrane and its contents.

Protoplasts and spheroplasts are spherical, regardless of the original shape of the bacterium.

Cell wall-deficient forms of bacteria may have a role in the persistence of certain chronic infections such as pyelonephritis.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, pg. 16.

questions.text: The antigenic nature of bacterial capsule is used in serological demonstration as the principal for:
questions.solution:
Capsular material is antigenic and may be demonstrated by serological methods. When a suspension of a capsulated bacterium is mixed with its specific anti- capsular serum and examined under the microscope, the capsule becomes very prominent and appears 'swollen'. This is capsular swelling or Quellung reaction.

It used to be a routine bedside procedure in the past for S. pneumoniae.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, pg. 18, 225.

questions.text: In a hot air oven, complete sterilisation is indicated by (chemical control is used):
questions.solution:
Browne's tube (green spot) is used in chemical sterilisation control in a hot air oven. A green colour is produced after 60 minutes at 160°C or 115 minutes at 150°C suggests complete sterilisation.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, pg. 30.

questions.text: In which of the following organisms, Kovac's method doesn't show smear turning dark within 5-10 seconds?
questions.solution:
Klebsiella is an oxidase negative bacteria.

In Kovac's method, the smeared area in the petri dish turns dark in 10 seconds indicating an oxidase positive reaction.

The remaining organisms are all oxidase positive.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, pg. 231.

questions.text: Malaria with trophozoite as infectious stage shows:
questions.solution:
Malaria with trophozoite as infectious state is seen in blood transfusion malaria. There are no hypnozoites. They have short incubation, absent relapses and no pre-erythrocytic schizogony.

The parasites may remain viable in blood bank for 1-2 weeks.

Reference - From 8th edition of Paniker's Textbook of parasitology pg 80.

questions.text: For the most common protozoan parasite globally, which of the following is not used in the lab diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Most common protozoan parasite is Toxoplasma gondii.

Modified ZN staining is not utilised in its diagnosis. Cryptosporidium parvum can be detected by modified ZN staining.

Reference - From 8th edition of Paniker's textbook of parasitology pg 94.

questions.text: A patient presents with hepatomegaly, pain, obstructive jaundice and urticaria. USG shows the 'water-lily' sign. What is the treatment of choice in early stage ?
questions.solution:
The above history indicates early infection by Echinococcus granulosus or dog tapeworm.

Ultrasonography is the diagnostic procedure of choice.

  • Cyst wall typically shows double echogenic lines separated by a hypoechoic layer (double contour).
  • Pathogenic findings include daughter cysts and the 'water-lily' sign due to detached endocyst floating within the cavity.

In early stages, the treatment of choice is puncture, aspiration, injection and reaspiration (PAIR).

Indications of PAIR include -

  • Cysts with internal echoes on ultrasound (snowflake sign).
  • Multiple cysts.
  • Cysts with detached laminar membrane.

Contraindications of PAIR include -

  • Superficially located cysts.
  • Cysts with multiple thick internal septal divisions (honeycombing pattern).
  • Cysts communicating with biliary tree.

Praziquantel 20 mg/kg/day for 2 weeks is usually given post surgically or for inoperable cysts.

Reference - From 8th edition Paniker's textbook of parasitology Pg 134.

choices.text: Demonstration can be done by scotch tape method

questions.text: For the given diagram, which of the following is applicable to the adult worm?
questions.solution:
The figure shows the embryo of Enterobius vermicularis which is tadpole-shaped.

Enterobius vermicularis is monoxenous, passing its entire life cycle in the human host.

The egg becomes infectious only 6 hours after being deposited on the skin. Under cool moist conditions, the egg remains viable for about 2 weeks.

Option a - Nematodes not showing systemic migration in man include -

  • Enterobius vermiculoris
  • Trichuris trichiura

Option c - Demonstration of the eggs can be done by scotch tape method (the mounted scotch tape is firmly pressed against the anal margin, covering all sides. It is later transferred to a glass slide and examined under the microscope).

Adult worm can be detected in finger nails or from stool after enema.

Option d - Females are infected more commonly than men.

Reference - From 8th edition Paniker's textbook of parasitology pg 198.

questions.text: In the tube coagulase test, which of the following is not utilised as an anticoagulant?
questions.solution:
Tube coagulase test detects free coagulase of S.aureus.

About 0.1ml of a young broth culture or agar culture suspension of the isolate is added to about 0.5 ml of human or rabbit plasma in a narrow test tube.

EDTA, oxalate or heparin may be used as the anticoagulant for preparing the plasma. Citrate is not recommended because it may be utilised by some contaminant bacteria, causing false positive results.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, pg 207.

choices.text: In serum broth : Flocculent without deposits
In serum broth : Granular turbidity without deposit
In Blood agar : Large, circular, opaque and concave discs with hemolysis around them
In Blood agar with bacitracin: Wide inhibition zone

questions.text: A 10 year old boy had history of sore throat for which medical treatment was not taken. A few weeks later, he complains of severe pain on swallowing and has swollen post auricular nodes. Biochemical reactions show a catalase negative organism, insoluble in 10% bile and producing no gas but fermenting sugars. Which of the following is true about its colonies?
questions.solution:
The most likely organism is Streptococcus pyogenes.

S. pyogenes are sensitive to bacitracin. After incubation with bacitracin paper disc, a wide zone of inhibition is seen with S.pyogenes, but not with other streptococci.

In liquid media, such as glucose or serum broth, growth occurs as a granular turbidity with a powdery deposit without any surface pellicle.

On blood agar, after incubation for 24 hours, the colonies are small, circular, semitransparent, low, convex discs with an area of clear hemolysis around them.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, pg 217.

choices.text: Its capsule is non type specific.
Shows R to S variation on subculture.
Capsular polysaccharide protects the cocci from phagocytosis.
Produce an oxygen labile hemolysin which contributes to virulence.

questions.text: An organism shows a wide zone of inhibition on application of optochin disc on a plate of blood agar, differentiating it from other streptococci. What is true about the organism?
questions.solution:
The organism described is S. pneumoniae.

  • Its capsular polysaccharide, because of its acidic and hydrophilic properties, protects the cocci from phagocytosis.
  • The capsule is a type specific antigen.
  • The pneumococcus shows S to R variation in subculture.
  • It produces an oxygen labile hemolysin does not contribute to virulence.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 225, 226.

questions.text: Which stain is used to distinguish the bacteria showing metachromatic nodules and polar bodies on Albert's stain, from Vincent's angina?
questions.solution:
Cornybacterium diphtheriae shows metachromatic nodules and polar bodies on Albert's stain.

Leishman-stained smear is done to rule out Vincent's spirochetes and fusiform bacilli (responsible for Vincent's angina) which clinically resembles diphtheria.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 242.

choices.text: Blood agar with low dose of penicillin

questions.text: For the given image, which medium has been used to distinguish it from aerobic spore bearing bacilli?
questions.solution:
The image shows medusa head appearance. This is seen when B anthracis is plated on an agar medium. This should not be attempted in the laboratory as the cultures are highly infectious due to the presence of spores.

Blood agar is a solid medium.

On solid medium containing 0.05-0.50 units of penicillin/ml, when B.anthracis is grown, in 3-6 hours, the cells become large and spherical, and occur in chains on the surface of the agar, resembling a string of pearls.

This 'string of pearls reaction' clearly differentiates B.anthracis from B.cereus and other aerobic spore bearers.

Reference- From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology Pg. 251.

questions.text: A gram negative rod shaped bacterium which is present in the enteric flora grows on ordinary media as large, greyish, moist discoid and at times mucoid colonies. It can cause UTI, diarrhoea, septicemia, neonatal sepsis and neonatal meningitis. Its IMViC test results in?
questions.solution:
The question describes E. Coli.

IMViC test: Four biochemical tests widely employed in the classification of Enterobacteriaceae are

  • Indole (I)
  • Methyl red (MR)
  • Voges-Proskauer (VP)
  • Citrate (C) utilisation.

This is generally referred to by the mnemonic IMViC.

E.coli is indole and MR positive, and VP and citrate negative (IMViC + + - -).

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology Pg 281.

questions.text: A patient complains of a slowly rising fever since 7 days with malaise, along with constipation, and a severe headache. On examination, there is relative bradycardia and a coated tongue is present. Blood and fecal samples are taken for lab diagnosis. For the responsible organism, which medium is highly selective, producing large black metallic colonies?
questions.solution:
The above history can indicate typhoid fever.

Wilson Blair medium (has sulphite) is an indicator medium.

Salmonella typhi reduces sulphite to sulphide to give a black metallic sheen on the colony.

Salmonellae are shed in feces throughout the course of the disease and even in convalescence, with varying frequency. Hence, fecal cultures are almost as valuable as blood cultures in diagnosis. Fecal samples are plated directly on MacConkey, DCA (Desoxycholate Citrate Agar) or XLD (Xylose Lysine Deoxycholate) and Wilson-Blair media. The last is highly selective and should be plated heavily.

  • On MacConkey and DCA media, salmonellae appear as pale colonies.
  • On XLD, they appear pink with a black centre.
  • On the Wilson-Blair medium, S. Typhi forms large black colonies, with a metallicsheen.

S. paratyphi A produces green colonies due to the absence of H2S production.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology pg. 303

questions.text: Which of the following diagnostic method is based on the principle of a soluble antigen combining with antibody and becoming suspended or sedimented?
questions.solution:
In precipitation reactions, the antigen is in a soluble form and, on combination with the antibody, sediments or remains suspended in the form of floccules. Examples of diagnostic precipitation tests include the Kahn and VDRL tests.

Agglutination reactions are used for the diagnosis of infections due to Salmonellae (Widal test) and and Rickettsiae (Weil-Felix test).

The Schick test is based on the ability of circulating antitoxin to neutralize the Diphtheria toxin given intradermally, and indicates immunity or susceptibility to the disease.

Reference - From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology Pg 112-120.

choices.text: Pilli adhesion is rapid and firm, they undergo antigenic and phase variation.
Controlled by the practice of Crede's method

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about the pathogen identified by rapid carbohydrate utilisation test and grows well on Thayer Martin medium?
questions.solution:
The organism is Neisseria gonorrhoea based on rapid carbohydrate utilisation test and culture on Thayer Martin medium.

Neisseria are antigenically heterogeneous. They are capable of changing their surface structures in vitro and in vivo, avoiding host defence.

Pili, which are hair-like structures that act as virulence factor promoting attachment to host cells and inhibiting phagocytosis. Pili undergo antigenic and phase variation.

They cause infection which may spread to the periurethral tissues, causing abscesses and multiple discharging sinuses (watercan perineum).

Almost always transmitted venereally, the only non-venereal infection is ophthalmia neonatoram. Once very common, this has been controlled by the practice of instilling 1% silver nitrate solution into the eyes of all newborn babies i.e. Crede's method.

Rapid carbohydrate utilisation test (RCUT) is a rapid sugar fermentation test that is based on the presence of preformed enzymes in the bacteria and is not dependent on the growth of bacteria in the sugar media. This is rapid and more sensitive and specific for N. gonorrhoea.

Reference -From The tenth edition of Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, pg 234, 235.
